DataElement.preferredName: Assessment New York Heart Association Class NewYorkHeartAssociationClassCode
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Examination of the body by auscultation, palpation, percussion, inspection, and olfaction.  (Taber's)_A finding associated with a patient based on the functional classification developed by the New York Heart Association (NYHA), for categorizing patients with defined or presumed cardiac disease. The classification system is based on the ability, or lack thereof, to engage in physical activity. The classification system comprises four classes, though NYHA Class III and Class IV are often aggregated for the purpose of outcomes analysis._The New York Heart Association Classification of cardiac disease.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Assessment New York Heart Association Class
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Examination of the body by auscultation, palpation, percussion, inspection, and olfaction.  (Taber's)_A finding associated with a patient based on the functional classification developed by the New York Heart Association (NYHA), for categorizing patients with defined or presumed cardiac disease. The classification system is based on the ability, or lack thereof, to engage in physical activity. The classification system comprises four classes, though NYHA Class III and Class IV are often aggregated for the purpose of outcomes analysis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Examination of the body by auscultation, palpation, percussion, inspection, and olfaction.  (Taber's)

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

Property.preferredDefinition: A finding associated with a patient based on the functional classification developed by the New York Heart Association (NYHA), for categorizing patients with defined or presumed cardiac disease. The classification system is based on the ability, or lack thereof, to engage in physical activity. The classification system comprises four classes, though NYHA Class III and Class IV are often aggregated for the purpose of outcomes analysis.

Concepts.definition: A finding associated with a patient based on the functional classification developed by the New York Heart Association (NYHA), for categorizing patients with defined or presumed cardiac disease. The classification system is based on the ability, or lack thereof, to engage in physical activity. The classification system comprises four classes, though NYHA Class III and Class IV are often aggregated for the purpose of outcomes analysis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 12/7/08 - released per Emily Honeycutt/Duke Clinical Research Institute

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The New York Heart Association Classification of cardiac disease.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: New York Heart Association Class I

ValueMeaning.preferredName: New York Heart Association Class I
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding associated with a patient with defined or presumed cardiac disease without limitations of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. (from The Criteria Committee of the New York Heart Association. Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Great Vessels. 9th ed. Boston, Mass: Little, Brown & Co; 1994:253-256.)

Concepts.longName: New York Heart Association Class I
Concepts.definition: A finding associated with a patient with defined or presumed cardiac disease without limitations of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. (from The Criteria Committee of the New York Heart Association. Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Great Vessels. 9th ed. Boston, Mass: Little, Brown & Co; 1994:253-256.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: New York Heart Association Class II

ValueMeaning.preferredName: New York Heart Association Class II
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding associated with a patient with defined or presumed cardiac disease with slight limitation of physical activity. They are comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. (from The Criteria Committee of the New York Heart Association. Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Great Vessels. 9th ed. Boston, Mass: Little, Brown & Co; 1994:253-256.)

Concepts.longName: New York Heart Association Class II
Concepts.definition: A finding associated with a patient with defined or presumed cardiac disease with slight limitation of physical activity. They are comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. (from The Criteria Committee of the New York Heart Association. Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Great Vessels. 9th ed. Boston, Mass: Little, Brown & Co; 1994:253-256.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: New York Heart Association Class III

ValueMeaning.preferredName: New York Heart Association Class III
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding associated with a patient with defined or presumed cardiac disease with marked limitation of physical activity. They are comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. (from The Criteria Committee of the New York Heart Association. Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Great Vessels. 9th ed. Boston, Mass: Little, Brown & Co; 1994:253-256.)

Concepts.longName: New York Heart Association Class III
Concepts.definition: A finding associated with a patient with defined or presumed cardiac disease with marked limitation of physical activity. They are comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, or dyspnea. (from The Criteria Committee of the New York Heart Association. Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Great Vessels. 9th ed. Boston, Mass: Little, Brown & Co; 1994:253-256.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: New York Heart Association Class IV

ValueMeaning.preferredName: New York Heart Association Class IV
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding associated with a patient with defined or presumed cardiac disease with inability to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms are present even at rest or minimal exertion. (from The Criteria Committee of the New York Heart Association. Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Great Vessels. 9th ed. Boston, Mass: Little, Brown & Co; 1994:253-256.)

Concepts.longName: New York Heart Association Class IV
Concepts.definition: A finding associated with a patient with defined or presumed cardiac disease with inability to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms are present even at rest or minimal exertion. (from The Criteria Committee of the New York Heart Association. Nomenclature and Criteria for Diagnosis of Diseases of the Heart and Great Vessels. 9th ed. Boston, Mass: Little, Brown & Co; 1994:253-256.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
